Directions
Light one chimney full of charcoal
. When all the charcoal is lit and covered with gray ash, pour out and arrange the coals on one side of the charcoal grate. Set cooking grate in place, cover grill, and allow to preheat for 5 minutes. Alternatively, set half the burners on a gas grill to the highest heat setting, cover, and preheat for 10 minutes.
Clean and oil
the grilling grate.
Serious Eats / Julia Hartbeck
Place stewed onions and juices (or sauerkraut, if using) in a 12-inch (or larger) cast iron skillet and add beer. Nestle hot dogs into onions (or sauerkraut).
Serious Eats / Julia Hartbeck
Place cast iron pan on hot side of grill and cook until simmering, about 7-10 minutes. Slide to cooler side of grill. If using a charcoal grill, cover grill with vents over the hot dogs. Cook with all vents open until hot dogs are heated through, about 10 minutes, turning once halfway through cooking. If using a gas grill, simply lower the cover (there will not be vents).
Serious Eats / Julia Hartbeck
Remove lid. Using tongs, remove hot dogs from onions or sauerkraut and place directly on cooking grates over hot side of grill. Cook, turning occasionally, until well browned and crisp, about 3 minutes total. Return to cast iron pan. Toast buns over hot side of grill if desired. Serve hot dogs with buns, mustard, and onions or sauerkraut.
Serious Eats / Julia Hartbeck
Special Equipment
Grill
,
chimney starter
, and
12-inch cast iron skillet
or 10-inch square disposable aluminum pan.
Notes
If using a disposable aluminum pan in step 3, it may require less time to heat the onions or sauerkraut to simmering.
